utterances: Mr.
McCRACKEN: Well, from what I understand is the way Western programming airs in Japan is - they can't really air on the main networks.
They basically air on, like, satellite or terrestrial television.
So it didn't really get the kind of wide audience that, just, programs that are made in Asia usually get.
The market penetration is that I think they call it.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, yeah.
It wasn't really exposed as big as it could be.
But you would think, I mean, just looking at the Powerpuff Girls, they seem to have been, at least in part, inspired by Japanese anime.
Mr.

McCRACKEN: Yeah, I thought of it - a lot of the action sequences that we have in the show were definitely inspired by anime, but the characters themselves are really inspired by Margaret and Walter Keene paintings from the '60s, if you're familiar with those.
Sure, the very big eyes.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, yeah.
It was kind of combination between them and like, you know, Jay Ward-type cartooning stuff.
But we always had, like, anime influence within our action sequences and stuff.
And so then, it was decided that maybe if they had a slightly different look - and it turned out to be not so slightly different - they might do better in Japan.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, yeah.

Some of the Asian networks came to us and they wanted to produce their own version of ""Powerpuff Girls,"" and they felt they could do well, but it needed to be done and produced by an Asian studio and sort of, like, you know, then, we can air it on, like, TV Tokyo or whatever.
And how did that changed them?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: They just really wanted to kind of re-envision the property.

And when the idea was first pitched to me, the first thing I thought of was ""Batman."" I mean, here is the character that's been reinterpreted so many different ways from the original Bob Kane version to the Adam West version to the Frank Miller version, and they all - its core is still ""Batman."" The foundation of the character is still the same.
So I said, well, as long you keep that core foundation the same, you know, feel free to, you know, reinterpret or re-imagine it in a way that you feel is going to better play in your marketplace.
And they come out being a lot less abstract.
They look like - well, not like real girls, but a lot more like real girls.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Mm-hmm.

Yeah, and I think maybe one reason that was is because things like fashion is such a big component in Japan, and they thought, well, you know, these tiny little bodies that I gave them, they really couldn't kind of dress them as well as they could if they kind of stretched them out and made them, you know, much more, a little human proportion.
And so girls in Japan will buy the same clothes that the Powerpuff Girls wear?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, possibly.
Yeah, maybe, or it's just, you know, it's just they get more diverse things in the drawing, you know?
They can have street clothes and then there are superhero outfits and various different things, and it's just like another visual element that they feel is important to their type of programming.
And if you saw them, if you just happened to turn on your TV and saw them, would you recognize them?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah.
The main designs are still the same, you know.
The -Blossom's a redhead and Buttercup's a brunette and, you know, Bubbles as, you know, the blonde pigtails.
And so iconically, they still feel the same.
Well, stay with us.

Joining us now is Amy Chozick, who wrote about altering cartoons in a recent Wall Street Journal article, ""Cartoon Characters Get Big Makeover for Overseas Fans."" She's with us from our bureau in New York City.
Nice to have you on the line.
Hi.
Nice to be here.
Thanks.
And it's not just the Powerpuff Girls who get transformed when they go abroad.
That's right.
More and more media companies are seeing this transcreation, as they call it, as necessary to make their properties really resonate overseas.
Give us some other examples, if you would.

Well, but I was wondering, but why was it like - do you have any idea why it was like, you know, because this is about alcohol, you know, and why is a little girl using like an alcohol attack or whatever?
I don't know.

Well, some other example - ""Sesame Street,"" when they launched - well, ""Sesame Street's"" been in India for a while, but they recently replaced Big Bird with Boombah, a Bhangra-dancing lion, which is a type of dance popular in Bollywood movies.
Mm-hmm.
In South Africa, ""Sesame Street"" has an HIV-positive Muppet.

Mattel realized recently that eight out of ten Japanese girls found American Barbie ugly, so they came up with a cuter version with brown hair and round eyes, and kind of look that would be more typical of something that Japanese kids would find attractive.
And I was fascinated by your example of the Disney characters in China, a place where kids did not grow up with our traditional images of Mickey and Minnie.
That's right.
This is fascinating.
This is a company that is so careful about its copyrights that, you know, it still has Western women playing Cinderella and Snow White in Hong Kong Disneyworld, and in Tokyo Disney.

Yet, it's come out with a line of Cuties, which is a line of, kind of - taking the Hello Kitty aesthetic of a little, tiny mouth and kind of a smushier face that is popular across Asia and launched that in China and Japan, and elsewhere.
And it's been enormously successful.
It is, it's a huge seller, especially in China where these kids didn't grow up with regular Mickey, as you said.
And another character who's undergone quite a transformation, or a number of them, Spiderman.
Oh, yes.
Spiderman came back - Peter Parker came back as Pavitr Prabhakar in India.
And rather than gaining his power from a radioactive spider, he gets his power from a mysterious yogi, and he sports a loincloth when he's fighting crime.
Does it have a spider pattern on it?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Oh, it might, actually.
A-ha, I have to check into that.
Yes.
And where does he keep his web - anyway, anyway.

We're talking with Amy Chozick, who's a foreign correspondent for the Wall Street Journal, and Craig McCracken, who's the creator of ""The Powerpuff Girls."" If you'd like to join us in our conversation about how and why these characters are transformed when they go abroad: 800-989-8255.
E-mail: talk@npr.org.
And let's talk with Michael(ph) who's on the line with us from Ann Arbor in Michigan.
Hi.
I just - I love your show.
I just want to say that I watched the Japanese version of ""Powerpuff Girls."" And one of the things I noticed was that Bubbles, one of her attacks was called Bubbles Champagne.
I was wondering why they made - why they decided to call it champagne, you know.
It's a little girl.
A-ha.
Craig McCracken, you have any idea?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Oh, I'm sorry, I didn't hear the caller.
He was saying that he watched the Japanese version of ""The Powerpuff Girls"" and one of her attacks - is that right, Bubble's attacks is called Bubbles Champagne?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: I believe so, yeah.
In ""PPGZ,"" the girls are actually given weapons.
And so, you know, they've got various different weapons that they used to fight crime with that, you know, or you know - my version, the girls just were kind of like Superman, you know…
Mm-hmm.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: …they kind of fly around and beat up people, but they didn't have any real accessories.
And so, in the Japanese version, they have accessories, I guess like the champagne bubble generator.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, yeah.
